newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: CRICKET-TAYLOR GAMBLES IN SEARCH OF AUSTRALIAN RUNS.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-TAYLOR GAMBLES IN SEARCH OF AUSTRALIAN RUNS.

text.p: Mark Taylor was only partially rewarded for his positive captaincy as Australia fought to assert their control in the second test match against West Indies on Sunday.
Determined to build on his side's first innings lead of 27 runs, Taylor declined an offer from the umpires to leave the field for bad light after tea.
At close of play on the third day at the Sydney Cricket Ground, Australia were 77 for two, an overall lead of 104 runs, with eight wickets in hand.
With two days left to play, the match is evenly balanced.
Although the home side used the extra time in the middle to score valuable runs, they also lost Taylor and number three Ricky Ponting to give the tourists some encouragement.
Ironically, Taylor may have saved his own wicket if he had walked off when the conditions deteriorated sharply after tea.
Shortly after making his decision, the left-handed opener edged a ball from fast bowler Ian Bishop to first slip, where Brian Lara took the catch at the second attempt.
Taylor, who scored 16 to prolong a run of indifferent form this season, added 51 runs for the first wicket with fellow opener Matthew Elliott.
Elliott, playing in only his second test, grew in confidence as the innings progressed to remain unbeaten on 45. Mark Waugh was the other not out batsman on two.
Bishop claimed his second wicket of the innings to complete a memorable day when Ponting edged a catch to wicketkeeper Courtney Browne with his score on four.
West Indies, who lost the first test in Brisbane by 123 runs, started the day on 156 for three in reply to Australia's first innings total of 331.
The tourists were eventually dismissed for 304 after losing their last six wickets for 75 runs during the afternoon session.
Middle order batsman Shivnarine Chanderpaul and Bishop both scored 48 before falling victim to wrist spinner Shane Warne.
Bishop attempted to bring up his maiden test half-century with a boundary but only succeeded in giving Elliott a catch at deep mid-wicket to end the West Indies innings just before tea.
Australia fast bowler Glenn McGrath triggered the collapse by removing left-hander Jimmy Adams for 30 and wicketkeeper Browne for a duck in the fourth over after lunch with the total on 229.
McGrath finished with figures of four for 82 from 31 overs.
Fellow paceman Jason Gillespie took two wickets on his test debut by bowling tail-enders Curtly Ambrose and Kenneth Benjamin in quick succession.
